content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

You are given a markdown-formatted text `md`. Write a function `q_and_a_extractor` to extract all text in the markdown sections Question and Answer (starting with `# Question` and `# Answer`, respectively) and return the answer in a tuple like `(question,answer)`. Strip any leading spaces and newlines from the extracted text.

```julia
function q_and_a_extractor(md::AbstractString)
    questions = findall(r"^# Question\n?", md)
    answers = findall(r"^# Answer\n?", md)

    if length(questions) != length(answers)
        throw(ErrorException("Unmatched question and answer sections."))
    end

    questions_offsets = [md[start:prevind(md, end)] for (i, start) in enumerate(questions)]
    answers_offsets = [md[start:prevind(md, end)] for (i, start) in enumerate(answers)]

    questions = map(x -> strip(String(x)), questions_offsets)
    answers = map(x -> strip(String(x)), answers_offsets)

    return zip(questions, answers)
end
```

This function works by finding all occurrences of `# Question` and `# Answer` in the markdown text using regular expressions. It then extracts the text between these headers and strips any leading spaces and newlines using the `strip()` function. The result is a tuple of question-answer pairs.
